Compiled by the Venerable Avalokitavrata
Tripiá¹­aka Master from the Western Regions, Chao-san Ta-fu
At that time, the heavenly beings, attached to pleasures and giving rise to joy,
After passing that period of time, each harbors sorrow and distress.
Like a tree about to flourish, with dense leaves spreading everywhere,
After passing that period of time, all see its withering and falling.
Saá¹ƒsÄra is like that tree, and the heavenly beings are the leaves.
Because of attachment to sensual pleasures, they are scattered and destroyed by impermanence.
Also, like during the rainy season, it rains everywhere in the sky,
Having rained down, it does not turn back; those pleasures are also like this.
Like an echo reverberating outside, arising due to the wind,
Deceptive and originally non-existent; those pleasures are also like this.ğŸ”½Also, like throwing a torch, it burns up the dry firewood,
Just as when a torch is thrown, it burns the dry firewood,
The fire of death burns extremely fiercely, burning those who are attached to pleasure.
For countless hundreds of thousands of lives, going and returning in cyclic existence,
Confused by greed and delusion, one does not give rise to the thought of leaving.
For many kinds of sensual pleasures, one indulges and enjoys them,
Becoming the cause for various sufferings, which one will experience after they cease.
Namely, birth, old age, death, and the suffering of separation from what one loves,
In this way, for oneself and others, each is unable to escape.
Seeing one fall, why not give rise to fear?
If there is no skillful means, I will also be like that.
Knowing this, one diligently practices, always contemplating impermanence,
This person, when life is about to end, will have no pain or suffering.
Relatives, friends, and associates, facing each other with grief and sadness,
At the time of great fear, worry and suffering cannot be replaced.
Those who live will perish, those who have not fallen will end up dead,
The power of death is strong, it seizes both the noble and the lowly.
If the gods are well-determined, they will not give rise to negligence,
Accumulating those wholesome roots, they will cut off all afflictions.
Accumulations are the basis for dispersal, youth is the destination for old age,
Life is invaded by death, each abiding in dependence on it.
This impermanence is like a fire, able to burn Mount Sumeru,
How much more so the gods and humans, like a gathering of plantain trees and foam.
One should know that conditioned phenomena, by their very nature, are not stable,
If they are permanent or blissful, how could there be even a little bit?
All sentient beings in the world know that death is not far away,
There is no skillful means to escape, they do not give rise to the path of antidotes.
As for one's own and others' physical forms, how can they last long?
Ignorance and darkness, without awareness, happiness is also like this.
All sentient beings do not cultivate pure good karma,
All are for the wheel of birth and death, split and destroyed.
Endowed with a hundred thousand kinds, in an instant all perish,
One should know that those who are born are all subdued by death.
If a person always delights in careless conduct with thoughts,
Lacking in causes of happiness, in vain they are grasped by Yama.
Relying on form and color, being vigorous and strong, attached to happiness and immediately scattered and lost,
The powerful Yama, this person delights in being close to him.
If one is close to Yama, it is the most contemptible,
Happiness and lifespan quickly all disappear.
If the gods are attached to the causes of happiness, for a long time neglecting good causes,
Blind and dark, without awareness, they are deceived by desire.
Without majestic virtue and radiance, faculties dull and mind scattered,
From that Heaven of YÄma, following karma one falls down.
Happiness only lasts for a while, old age always cuts at the body,
If one gives rise to an attached mind, they are eyeless and without wisdom.
In the most wonderful happiness, enjoying without weariness or abandonment,
Unaware in an instant, the fear of death suddenly arrives.
The foolish have no contentment, not thinking of old age and death,
Later, when life is about to end, regret and distress are just like this.
Moreover, the happiness in the heavens, contemplating one can attain,
When one falls and perishes, where does that happiness go?
Happiness quickly passes away, lifespan is also like this,
Before long, in one's own body, one will certainly attain without doubt.
If in the time of strength and health, pure wisdom and mind are clear,
Those who delight in seeking the true Dharma are the ones endowed with wisdom.
All pleasures come to an end, all loves are separated,
All lives end in death, before death one should practice and study.
The fear of death is extremely dangerous, only the Dharma can save and deliver,
Therefore, always delight in it, and you will be born in a place of peace and security.
Because of delighting in the true Dharma, one is born among the gods,
If one falls away from there, then there is little suffering.
When an ordinary person is about to die, their mind has little joy,
Even though they have many friends, not one will accompany them a single step.
Whatever one has done in life, at the time of death it all appears before them,
The terror is known only by oneself, while relatives and loved ones surround them in vain.
Moreover, when their life is about to end, they give rise to discrimination towards others,
Out of delusion they cling to them as their own, and give rise to great fear at death.
The objects of the senses are like a snake's bite, and the poison of craving is like fainting,
The gods do not understand this, and are invaded and ravaged by death.
Moreover, when they perish in the heavens, they may be reborn among humans,
They should contemplate carefully, that the suffering of birth and death follows one.
Following the wind of karma, one experiences the suffering of expedient means,
In the world, there are those who are upright, who should subdue the mind and avoid death.
Neither parents, relatives, nor friends and servants,
When this person's life ends, they go forth alone in misery.
By nature, they deceive themselves, and when they die, they have no companions,
With their relatives and wives and children, they single-mindedly think of them in vain.
Moreover, those relatives and family members, not a single one is able to save them,
Terrified, with no one to rely on, they look at each other like strangers.
Foolish people have no knowledge or understanding, and now their life is wasted in vain,
Each receiving their own bitter retribution.
If one is afraid of suffering, why not be so of death?
Aspiring to seek the true Dharma, one will attain true and eternal bliss.
Because the devas are attached to pleasure, they are dull and unclear,
All are impermanent, how can happiness last long?
Illusory dharmas immediately flow and change, the true nature is always unmoving,
The devas abandon their palaces, because they do not rely on the true Dharma.
If the mind is agitated and disturbed, indulging in the five desires,
Not knowing the limit of one's lifespan, one will experience sharp and bitter suffering.
Perhaps they will pass away from that heaven and be reborn in another heaven,
But in the end, there will be a time of falling, just as there is night after the end of the day;
The day is the same as one's lifespan, the night is a metaphor for death,
Clearly understanding those two aspects, one should skillfully cultivate the mind.
Desiring objects bind sentient beings, for a long time they are not free,
They become the demon of death, and before long they are subdued.
Women are often deceitful and beguiling, with sweet words they serve and attend to each other,
Foolish people, when they die, will themselves experience the retribution of their karma.
In the past, in the excellent gardens and forests, with fragrant breezes and pure ponds and marshes,
They indulged in much play and enjoyment, where did the happiness go?
That happiness is certain to change, this body is certain to perish,
How is it called being a man?
Always being driven by greed.
Whether suffering or happiness, old or young, strong or weak,
Whether superior or inferior, all are conquered by impermanence.
Whether handsome or ugly, strong or weak,
Whether close or distant, all are conquered by impermanence.
Whether the king's messenger or the elder's attendant,
All are subdued by impermanence.ğŸ”½Whether poor or wealthy,
Whether virtuous or not,ğŸ”½Whether male or female,
All are subdued by impermanence.ğŸ”½Whether guests or hosts,
Whether dwelling in water or on land,ğŸ”½Whether residing on mountain peaks,
All are subdued by impermanence.ğŸ”½Whether sleeping or awake,
Whether eating, drinking, or feasting,ğŸ”½Whether going or coming,
All are subdued by impermanence.ğŸ”½Whether dwelling in the sky or on the ground,
Whether in the central plains or borderlands,ğŸ”½Like a spinning saw that never stops,
All are subdued by impermanence.ğŸ”½Whether possessing wisdom or wealth,
Whether diligent or indolent,ğŸ”½Whether sick or at ease,
All are subdued by impermanence.ğŸ”½Whether violent or kind,
Whether frugal or extravagant,ğŸ”½Whether enlightened or deluded,
All are subdued by impermanence.
Or in the hells, hungry ghosts, animals, or human realms,
Whether lazy or diligent, they are all conquered by impermanence.
If the gods in the desire realm, or those abiding in the form realm,
Due to their lack of power, they are all conquered by impermanence.
If the gods and humans in the formless realm, abiding in meditative absorption,
They too have no power, and are all conquered by impermanence.
If phenomena arise from causes, they will certainly disintegrate,
I have never seen anything created that can remain forever.
The faults of the five desires can be eliminated by the power of wisdom,
If one is free from craving and attachment, one can escape the ocean of existence.
That is, whether animate or inanimate, all will eventually be destroyed,
Understanding the nature of the world to be like this, the mind should delight in tranquility.
Gardens, forests, precious mountains, palaces with exquisite adornments,
The conflagration of the eon burns everything, and the gods all retreat and disappear.
The foolish mind is indulgent, and the objects of the senses are endless.
Bound by the rope of desire, like a mute, one falls from there.
Life and joy are thus abandoned,
Blind and without sight, one loses the right path.
Moreover, the lives of all beings are like floating bubbles,
Toppled by the waves of desire, how can youthful beauty last long?
The people of Tuá¹£ita Heaven are oppressed by the fire of impermanence,
Like the light of a lamp extinguished when the oil is used up, quickly passing by like this.
Karmic fruits are like a wheel, the twelve links are like spokes,
Each is pulled by its cause, arising and ceasing, spinning together.
Abandoning the wonderful bliss of the heavens, the adorned and excellent realms,
One again experiences that cycle of rebirth, subdued by destruction.
Because of being subdued by cessation, the root of suffering increases,
Cycling in the three realms, unable to escape any suffering.
Moreover, when those gods fall, the other gods rejoice,
Because of this anger and distress, they transmigrate without rest.
When merit is exhausted, power falls back, drifting and drowning in the ocean of existence,
Whether it is happiness or suffering, the cause is self-received without error.
Because of cultivating good karma in the past, one is born among the gods,
Attached to pleasure and neglecting the cause of purity, gradually it is exhausted.
If the cause does not increase, how can that merit last long?
It is all due to impermanence, everything is scattered and lost.
All conditioned forms and appearances are all false and impermanent,
Sentient beings are attached to false thoughts, not delighting in relying on the correct Dharma.
The gods are addicted to the pleasures of desire, swiftly like a waterfall,
Life passes in an instant, yet the foolish do not realize it.
One creates unwholesome karma oneself, and thus invites old age and death.
Those gods are not rightly aware, always pursuing objects of desire.
What happiness is there in the three realms?
All are impermanent, blinded by delusion, unable to seek the way out.
Just as heavy rain pours down from the sky,
its force does not pause for a moment, so too is happiness.
Like dust and sand blown by the wind, temporarily abiding in the sky,
deluded karma forms a body, yet one does not know where it will fall.
Sentient beings have no permanence, and happiness also does not last long.
Foolish people have no right thoughts, and that happiness cannot be obtained.
Increasing various desires and pleasures is the cause of samsara.
If one does not understand it well, one will be destroyed by it.
Dwelling together in mutual need,ğŸ”½Like a beautiful flower garland,
Covering a poisonous snake.
Like poison mixed with delicious food, Once eaten, one will die.
If one becomes attached to sensual pleasures, One will certainly sink into evil destinies.
All conditioned phenomena, All return to birth, abiding, and cessation.
Those pleasures are also like this, The mind falsely generates attachment to them.
Due to falsely generating greed, One immediately undergoes momentary transmigration.
Pleasure and life, Will soon be abandoned.
If one delights in practicing wholesome deeds, From beginning to end, without laziness,
Due to the mind being tranquil, One will have no worries or regrets at the time of death.
Form and appearance will certainly be exhausted, Kindness and love will ultimately part and separate.
The foolish have no thoughts or considerations, Always attached to the objects of desire.
Old age and death revolve like a wheel, Swift and difficult to guard against,
Sentient beings lack the eye of wisdom, and are thus divided.
When the gods fall, their faculties and consciousness are all confused,
And their relatives all abandon them - that suffering has no parallel.
Experiencing various desires and pleasures, their greedy minds are insatiable,
And when their lives end here, they undergo various sufferings and afflictions.
If a person performs good deeds, they will certainly avoid the evil paths,
And later, when their lives are about to end, they will have no worries or fears.
Until they pass away, their meritorious rewards will be complete,
And they will naturally attain great benefits - this is the foremost peace and security.
The gods call it falling, while humans call it untimely death,
Knowing that it is impermanent, why create further evil?
Just as when the oil and wick are exhausted, one knows the lamp will definitely go out,
When meritorious karma is exhausted, one will lose the heavenly palace.
Just as when a wall is painted, if the wall is destroyed, how can the painting remain?
When pleasure decays, merit diminishes, and one falls, there is no doubt.
The gods abandon their excellent abodes, attached to pleasure in this way,
All sentient beings should realize the impermanent nature of phenomena.
The living are devoured by death, the flourishing is oppressed by decline,
The four elements suddenly increase and decrease, how can one avoid the afflictions of illness?
If there are many births, destructions are also limitless,
After destruction, they are born again, and after birth, they immediately age.
In an instant, a great fear will suddenly arrive,
Transmigrating without a moment's pause, why are humans unaware?
Moreover, all sentient beings, the young quickly change,
Life is fleeting and impermanent, why are humans unaware?
Pushed forward day by day, in an instant they perish,
Being dragged around by karma, why are people unaware?
Hundreds of thousands of koá¹­is of devas, freely playing and enjoying themselves,
Yet they still fall down, why are people unaware?
Moreover, the devas of the six desire heavens, attached to pleasures,
Because of this, they perish, why are people unaware?
Pleasures are like dreams and illusions, also the same as bubbles,
Temporarily existing, then scattered and destroyed, why are people unaware?
Also like those mirages, arising from false thoughts,
Foolish people dwell in saá¹ƒsÄra, why do they not give rise to disgust?
This death is the most frightening, there is no expedient to escape it,
Whether it is a house or a heavenly palace, which can last long?
Pleasures are all abandoned, immeasurable suffering oppresses,
Relatives are all separated, this is called death.
Because of being covered by delusion and right wisdom, one goes to that great fear,
The extremely deep and vast sea of suffering, this is called death.
All the faculties are dull and inferior, life is about to end in an instant,
Abandoning good reputation and fame, this is called death.
Regarding the enjoyment of objects and praise, etc.,
Because of losing them all, this is called death.
Endowed with certainty and truth, being the support for sentient beings,
Able to destroy the homogeneity of sentient beings, this is called death.
If gods, dragons, yakshas, and various ghosts and spirits,
When the time comes, all return to exhaustion, this is called death.
Like a wild horse running, like a raging fire pressing,
All are unable to endure, this is called death.
Life, warmth, and consciousness are all abandoned, the aggregates and sense bases are all scattered and destroyed,ğŸ”½...
This Dharma is the most impartial, and it is called death.
Thus, all sentient beings flow and change without a moment's rest.
One should leave behind an indulgent mind and diligently cultivate wholesome actions.
Like the wind and flying birds, their nature is extremely swift and agile.
The lifespan of those sentient beings passes even faster than that.
The force of the wind can turn back, and birds can return,
But once the life of sentient beings ends, their empty love cannot be regained.
Form and color all change and decay, and meritorious actions are all consumed.
They are seized by the powerful Yama King.
The suffering of death is extremely perilous and evil, destroying all sentient beings.
Swift and without a moment's pause, why are they unaware?
The gods are mostly indulgent, attached to pleasure and deluded by folly.
They do not know the great suffering and distress that they will definitely experience.
It means that the nature of conditioned phenomena is impermanent,
And fear arises accordingly, gradually leading to destruction.
Youth is invaded by old age, and life is devoured by death,
Because of abiding in the cause of destruction, various calamities arise.
Because the gods are heedless, their minds are crazed by desire,
And they do not give rise to worry or fear regarding these various evils.
The eye of wisdom clearly sees the fruits of suffering in the future,
The wise contemplate well, while fools give rise to reversals.
Because the mind creates evil, they deceive themselves,
Merit diminishes and life ends, like a lamp going out when the oil is exhausted.
Regarding the supreme and wonderful pleasures, gardens, forests, and excellent objects,
One does not enjoy them to one's fill, and thus falls down.
Life is not solid and firm, like a floating bubble,
Suddenly having and then returning to nonexistence, ordinary beings are also like this.
Like foam blown by the wind, it can still be temporarily stopped,
If the blessings of those gods are exhausted, they cannot stay for even a moment.
If a person is attached to sensual pleasures, they will be controlled by greed,
Turning and turning, they will seek more and more, not knowing that death is approaching.
Because of indulging in craving and love, they increase moment by moment,
How can they know that their lifespan is gradually decreasing?
Youth and vigor suddenly decay, like being beaten with a stick,
When sickness comes and invades one's comfort and ease, the harm is also like this.
These three kinds of faults can destroy gods and asuras,
Because ordinary beings are deluded, they see but are not alarmed.
Observing oneself and others, relatives and friends, like saliva and mucus that do not cease,
Because of this and that delusion and love, they mutually entangle and bind each other.
If a person is greedy for lineage, with children and grandchildren continuing the line,
They are like a silkworm binding itself, ultimately what is to be gained?
Life is difficult to protect, the enemy of death has great power,
Its speed does not pause for a moment, in an instant it is close.
Not by gods, humans, asuras, ghosts, or various other kinds,
Only the World-Honored Buddha, the rest have no power to subdue.
Well understanding power and weakness, revealing the true Dharma,
Not creating the causes of various offenses, forever leaving behind that perilous path.
If a person delights in indulgence, this is said to be not liberation,
Because they are deluded by that foolishness, going away from enlightenment is far.
Those who do not delight in indulgence, regard indulgence as an enemy,
Because of this, the gods then fall into hell.
If sentient beings are indulgent, they will sink in birth and death,
If the mind is free from those faults, its nature is originally pure.
Not being negligent is supreme, like savoring nectar;
If one is negligent and deluded, drinking poison will lead to death.
Moreover, the negligent are like a raging poisonous fire,
Because of this, they create for themselves a long time of burning and boiling.
In all worlds, the unconditioned is the most tranquil;
This person who is not negligent will attain to that place.
If a person indulges in negligence, always creating unwholesomeness,
They are obscured by delusion - how can they be born in the heavens?
Negligence will lead to destruction, being free from this is always peaceful and secure;
Evil and vile, deeply to be detested - therefore one should cast it far away.
If a person is not negligent, they are revered by the world;
Always free from perversion, this is called a righteous person.
How can one become attached to joy and pleasure, and give rise to the faults of negligence?
If the mind is not restrained, one will be subdued by the demon of death.
Joy and pleasure are like blazing smoke, and negligence is like a raging fire,
Burning countless gods, deluded and unaware.
If one does not cut off negligence, one will always be a person in cyclic existence,
Confused by objects, unable to seek liberation.
Negligence drags the gods, causing them to fall into danger,
Therefore, the wise say that negligence is poison.
Pleasure is like honey, and negligence is addiction,
Later, when one experiences bitter fruits, one will suffer the pain oneself.
Negligence brings about danger and misfortune, which the wise all understand,
The foolish are not disgusted with it, like a cow that is no different.
If one delights in practicing negligence, this person only has suffering,
Carelessness is not a good cause, and little happiness cannot be obtained.
Through carefulness one can attain the peaceful state of mind, the place of death,
But through carelessness one can only invite the suffering of hell.
The gods are attached to carelessness, indulging in ignorance and lack of wisdom,
They are then the same as those of different destinies, dull and ignorant, all similar.
Those gods are extremely careless, enjoying various transformations,
Claiming to always dwell in the heavenly palace, not knowing that they will fall.
Moreover, those heavenly beings know the proper measure and enjoy happiness,
If lust and indulgence are excessive, the loss and destruction are their own fault.
In the wonderful happiness of the heavens, greedily attached without temporary abandonment,
Meritorious karma then decreases accordingly, knowing that one will fall and perish.
Showing the faults of carelessness, the gods should permanently cut it off,
Because of not abandoning attachment, they fall from the Heaven of the Thirty-three.
Fools delight in negligence, giving rise to various faults and evils.
When their lives end there, they are tormented by the fires of desire.
The five desires are like the earth, negligence arises dependent on them.
Always indulging in defilement and delusion, they do not cultivate meritorious deeds.
Desire is the cause of negligence, violent evil is extremely swift and sharp.
The wise should restrain it, knowing that it is all like a dream.
A dream is not a cause for hell, the five desires are precisely the cause.
One should be apart from the five desires and diligently cultivate supreme practices.
The gods obtain all pleasures according to their thoughts.
If they are well enlightened with wisdom, they will be diligent and not negligent.
The gods dwell in palaces, deluded by objects.ğŸ”½Negligent and without liberation, they sink and drown in the ocean of suffering.
Negligence is extremely deluded and dark, with ignorance as its basis.
Covered by that delusion, though seeing, it is as if blind.
Also, like a blazing flame, it arises due to fire,
And carelessness gives rise to afflictions, which arise due to delusion.
If the mind gives rise to carelessness, it is then burned by it.
Thus, a foolish person will fall into hell.
The gods give rise to carelessness, attached to the celestial maidens,
Enjoying the bliss of union, unaware of the suffering of separation.
When the gods' lives are about to end, they approach great terror,
Bliss is not firm, at this time they vainly regret.
What is united will eventually separate, what is attached to bliss is destroyed by suffering,
The young will soon grow old, all will return to extinction.
Moreover, those sentient beings, bound by good and evil karma,
Each go to various destinies, like actors and actresses.
Because of being pulled by karma, one follows the flow of saá¹ƒsÄra,
When the retribution is exhausted, one is impermanent, and the wise cannot avoid it.
Carelessness is very detestable, and one should always stay away from it by skillful means.
If one can cut off those faults, one will transcend the ocean of the three existences.
Just as a person falling from a deep cliff may have a little life left,
If one falls due to carelessness, one cannot obtain the slightest pleasure.
Because of the fault of carelessness, one creates immeasurable evil karma,
And in the daytime and nighttime, there is no little goodness.
All the happiness in the world and beyond the world,
Is destroyed by carelessness, therefore one should abandon it.
Carelessness quickly destroys, being apart from it is peaceful,
Later one is born among the gods, becoming the supreme lord of the gods.
If a person is apart from carelessness, one cuts off the cause of saá¹ƒsÄra,
Therefore, one should abandon it, and always be free from sorrow and fear.
If a person seeks pleasant results, they should remove the causes of suffering.
If one cuts off that heedlessness, then there will be no difficulties and hardships.
Moreover, those who are attached to heedlessness give rise to sleepiness,
And due to the causes and conditions of evil thoughts, they will fall into a dangerous cliff.
Heedfulness is supreme, do not allow even a little to arise.
Abandoning it, one always obtains peace; being attached to it, one is bound by it.
Because the gods are heedless, they become increasingly deluded and intoxicated,
Like birds that know nothing, always engaging in actions that lead to hell.
Immeasurable gods and humans are fettered by desire,
Falling into the ocean of heedlessness, like fish thrown into a net.
Moreover, the sentient beings in the heavens, addicted to desire and lacking awareness,
Are bound by the mind of heedlessness, how can that pleasure last long?
The mind follows and turns with heedlessness, and objects are always present.
Without aversion to pleasure, those gods are always suffering.
The gods who are attached to desire all come from heedlessness.
This Dharma is not firm and solid, and can destroy life.
Immeasurable hundreds of thousands of myriads of koá¹­is of nayutas of gods,
Burned by the fire of desire, due to foolish heedlessness.
That fault of heedlessness can cause sentient beings
To create unwholesome causes, and later reap their bitter fruits.
Observing well the true nature of that heedlessness,
It is like a poisonous snake, and also like a sharp sword.
Heedlessness causes the gods to all follow and turn,
First seen as close friends, later realized as enemies.
Gods, humans, asuras, and those dragons,
All arise due to negligence, thus giving rise to various obstacles.
Being deluded by negligence, one is unable to cultivate various wholesome deeds,
This person loses great benefits and seeks to enter a perilous and evil path.
If a person always delights in attachment to food, drink, and union,
Engaging in animal-like behavior, they are deceived by negligence.
Moreover, those heavenly beings, far from various wholesome deeds,
Gradually indulge in foolishness and delusion, what benefit is there in negligence?
Because the gods are negligent, their blessings are exhausted and they fall,
Blown by the winds of karma, they drift and sink into evil destinies.
For countless hundreds of thousands of eons, they revolve in the suffering of birth and cessation,
Lacking right mindfulness and contemplation, they always give rise to various worries and fears.
The gods, due to their foolishness, drink the turbid water of negligence,
Later falling into the hells, where fierce fires always surround them.
If a person in the world always delights in being vigilant,
Diligent in cultivating meritorious deeds, they will certainly be reborn in the heavens.
The human body is extremely difficult to obtain, yet having obtained it, one becomes negligent;
Negligence is extreme darkness, which will lead to the suffering of hell.
If a person delights in negligence and does not give rise to compassion,
When their life ends there, they will experience extreme suffering and distress.
Not burned by worldly fire, nor cut by swords and weapons,
This blazing fire of negligence arises from the five faculties.
Pleasure perishes and becomes suffering, and relatives are also like enemies,
All arising from negligence, therefore one should abandon it.
Negligence, delusion, and craving cause greed to increase and grow,
These three kinds of fearsome things can destroy the goodness of sentient beings.
Lacking wisdom, abandoning the true Dharma, delighting in being negligent,ğŸ”½...
The messengers of Yama will drive you at the time of death.
Laziness is extremely dangerous; the wise always guard against it.
At the time of death, they are at ease and have no fear.
Laziness is the greatest suffering; non-laziness is the greatest joy.
If one seeks that joy, one should not be lazy.
In that place, realm, and so forth, laziness gives rise to faults.
It destroys all wholesome roots and creates obstacles.
Moreover, the lazy one delights in form and color,
Due to excessive ignorance, one then goes to danger.
If one is always lazy, one will definitely fall into a bad path.
The fool does not realize that death is in the palm of one's hand.
Because the blessings of the gods are exhausted, they all become lazy,
They are harmed by that, falling and unable to be saved.
Endowed with all merits,
Always in accord with patience, and compassionate towards sentient beings.
By the power of this wholesome root, at the time of death, one is free from all fears.
Therefore, abandon heedlessness, and concentrate on diligent practice,
Always stay far away from foolishness, and well protect one's wisdom.
If one penetrates these two dharmas, heedlessness will be naturally eliminated.
This is the wealth of a great man, which one should definitely cultivate and practice.
Because of possessing that wealth, one will delight in heedfulness.
Heedlessness is called bondage, while heedfulness is liberation.
These two kinds of characteristics should be discerned with skillful means.
If one delights in heedlessness, one should arouse wholesome thoughts,
And at the time of death later on, one will know the fruits of one's karma.
Moreover, one should abandon householders and always be content,
Diligent practice of all wholesome deeds leads to the bliss of approaching nirvana.
Departing from worldly attachments, solely pursuing the truth,
One is not moved by the affairs of demons, not even a little bit.
If one's mind is tranquil, always free from all desires,
Superior wisdom will arise, so how can there be suffering for them?
With right wisdom, one contemplates past and present fears,
And will be liberated from future immeasurable afflictive bonds.
